column4: I installed ubuntu on my laptop recently, but wasn't able to create a swap space because I had too many partitions. I had my Windows partition, and the computer came with a system restore partition and some data storage partition. I can't add another partition, because I have too many. I want a swap space, because there are times when Ubuntu needs more memory, and I would usually have to do a hard restart. Is there any way to have
you can use a swap file on your root partition
good idea...
yeah thats true
My original problem was that I wanted a swap space, but I have too many partitions. All the partitions are mandatory for Windows and Ubuntu, so I can't get rid of any. how can i put in a swap space?
you cant, unless you delete one partition and make it an extened one, but you should have done that before installtion, you can alternatively use a swap file instead
What's a swap file
its a file thats beeing used as swap space instead of a partition
how do I make one?
tried google?
somewhere on your root partition
root partition? I only have one ubuntu partition with a mount point of /
file system ext3
yeah that one, put it somewhere on there, maybe as /swap or so
so... in a folder called swap in my / directory?
o just name the file swap it doesnt need a own directory
thanks, i am just really cautious after I accidentally made my windows partition a swap space, i lost everything
/dev/zero is a special device that returns zeros, the other one is the output file dd writes count*bs into
so in that case it reads 512mb of zeros and puts them into the file specified with the of= parameter
so if I were to make the swap file, I would use that command, and after of= i would just put /swap.swap?
yeah
